Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Thermochemistry of Nanoceramics: Understanding and Controlling Phase Transformation and Sintering via Interface Energetics
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Ceramic materials often exhibit novel physical and chemical properties as their sizes approach nanometer dimensions. These new properties have inspired a variety of new applications in several fields, ranging from nanosensors to cathode materials for fuel cells and lithium batteries. As well, the possibility is opened for the development of new materials in response to the current energy problems such as the U.S. increasing demand for energy, dependence on foreign oils, and climate change. However, the optimization of nanoceramic processing is still a challenge, and understanding the fundamental concepts requires further research. Within this project, Prof. Castro focuses on the larger volume fraction of interfaces present in nanoceramics to improve processing control. He hypothesizes that manipulation of the interface composition can be used to change processing and product properties on a thermodynamic basis. In particular, Prof. Castro works on improving densification and phase transformation, two fundamental parts of processing, by controllably changing interface energies by tuning composition, enabling faster, less expensive, and more controlled processing and products. This unique thermodynamic approach is carried out by providing unprecedented data on interface energetics (rarely found in the literature) on technologically important materials, bringing those significant advances closer to industrial manufacturing. The project also has an important educational component that focuses on the promotion of engineering in middle and high-schools. The program, Materials&You, involves demonstrations of interesting processing and properties at school events to expose students to basic materials' concepts. Two high-schools with significant Latin American students and the underlying goal of getting all students to graduate have been selected.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This project uses unique calorimetric techniques to measure interface energies of nanoceramics and use them to improve the control of sintering and phase transformation by monitoring and manipulating driving forces. The aim is to quantify the effects of dopants on the interface energies and correlate them with processing parameters and kinetics. The effect of dopants in processing is typically considered exclusively on a kinetic basis, but with the advent of high-resolution calorimetry available at the University of California at Davis laboratories (recently developed by the Prof. Castro and collaborators), Prof. Castro's group is capable of quantifying the effect of composition change on the energetics of the system, opening a new avenue for processing control. Within this project, high-temperature drop solution calorimetry is used to measure the interface energies (both surface and grain boundary) of three technologically relevant oxides: tin dioxide, zinc oxide, and zirconia, and those data correlated with sintering and polymorphic stability. The better understanding of the role of interface energetics and dopants in nanoceramic processing enables improvement of composition design in industries, enabling more energy and cost efficient products, with predictable phases/sizes/densities. From the educational perspective, students participating in the project are mentored and work with strategic materials and processes, providing training for their future careers as materials' professionals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intelectional Merit: The main purpose of this project was to establish a strong research group dedicated to providing fundamental understanding on the effect of interfaces energies on the processing and control of ceramic nanomaterials. Interface energies are the excess energies from the exposed interfaces of crystals, which in nanoscaled systems account for a large fraction of the total energy. Despite this enormous energetic contribution, the modification of energy using compositional changes have not been used as controlling parameters to induce particular microstructural evolutions. The PI's group, established via this project, has demonstrated in this past five years that controlling energetics can indeed lead to unprecedented control during ceramic processing. The scientific community started accepting this concept after direct experimental demonstrations (using calorimetry) quantifying the role of interface energies in ceramic nanomaterials. The unquestionable results have been reported in the form of publications in high impact journals and talks in world-class conferences. One of the most relevant publications was an Invited Feature paper in the Journal of the American Ceramic Society, where the PI of the project could elaborate on the summary of the achievements of this project. This is a great honor reserved for experienced and respected researchers, which speaks for another reached goal of the project, which was to launch the career of the PI and make him a leader in the ceramic field, with independent and novel transformational ideas. The accomplishments were all linked to novel calorimetric methods developed within this project, that enable quantification of the interface energetics in the tested systems. The project started with a model material, tin dioxide, but evolved to more complex compositions of more industrial relevance (yttria-zirconia). The results pointed out that regardless of the system, the energetic control is key to predict microstructures and properties during processing. As another key outcome, the PI and his group have reported a new concept of phase diagram where the size of the particles is taken into account. This new nanoscale phase diagram was reported for zirconia and tin dioxide with different dopants, and is the greatest advance in years in the understanding of nanoscale effect for predictable and reliable nanotechnologies. 

Broader Impacts: This project had strong impact on education of a well-capacitated workforce and inspiring new generations of engineers via outreach programs. Two graduate students, one being only partially supported, have been trained in this project, both finding jobs in a high-tech company where their skills are used to develop new technologies in an U.S. based industry. Undergraduates have also been trained by doing short research projects, and the skills helped them finding positions in national laboratories, industry or graduate schools. The PI has developed a program where two alternative high-schools, designed to discourage students from leaving school before they graduate, have been visited (Midtown School and Einstein Education Center) aiming to exploit the PI’s Hispanic heritage to access underrepresented students (~50% Latin Americans), expanding the educational materials activities' impacts to a necessary social benefit with mentoring of those students by the PI himself. The program, called Materials & You, inspired the students in an unprecedented way, as confirmed by surveys. The PI also created within this project the Materials Magic Show, where students for the Materials Advantage chapter at UC Davis perform a theatrical  event with spetacular materials properties demonstrations. More than 3,000 people have attended the show that takes place yearly during the UC Davis open hous (Picnic Day). These initatives will be continued with other funding opportunities, guaranteeing the future of these positive enterprises.
